results:
Based on my search results, I can provide you with comprehensive information about the cultural impact of the BBC adaptations of Jane Eyre from 1983 and 2006.

## The 1983 BBC Adaptation (Timothy Dalton & Zelah Clarke)

The 1983 adaptation is noted for being extremely faithful to Charlotte Brontë's original text, with "dialogue lifted almost entirely from the original novel."(no content)This eleven-episode serial starred Zelah Clarke as Jane Eyre and Timothy Dalton as Edward Rochester.

### Cultural Impact and Reception:

Timothy Dalton's performance is particularly praised for conveying Rochester's "black hole of despair" after "a decade of his life in utter despair, lonely, living with an ugly, life-destroying secret."(no content)Many consider "Timothy Dalton's Rochester is probably the best ever."(no content)The 1983 version is praised for having "the time to develop the central relationship between Rochester and Jane" and being "truer to Bronte's full vision (with her attention to class, status, gender)."(no content)Some viewers believe "Timothy Dalton is every bit as good as Toby Stephens from the 2006 miniseries" and "perhaps even a little bit closer to the character in the book."

## The 2006 BBC Adaptation (Toby Stephens & Ruth Wilson)

This four-part BBC television drama serial adaptation was broadcast in the United Kingdom on BBC One.(no content)The adaptation was "generally considered a successful adaptation, garnering critical acclaim and a number of nominations from various award bodies."

### Cultural Impact and Critical Reception:

The Guardian praised it, stating "The new BBC version shows that it is [...] possible to make successful drama by telling the story straight. It features an excellent performance from Toby Stephens, who manages to make Rochester simultaneously macho and vulnerable, and also from Ruth Wilson as a quizzical, strong and un-neurotic Jane."(no content)One viewer called it "one of the best series the BBC have ever produced and in Toby Stephens Rochester we saw one of the greatest performances seen on British television."(no content)The 2006 adaptation is described as "many people's favourite version, and which gives the 1983 adaptation above a real run for its money."

## Comparative Cultural Impact:

### Acting Performances:
About the 2006 version: "I was completely captivated by both Ruth Wilson and Toby Stephens. They really brought the story to life for me in way that has haunted me days after viewing it."(no content)Ruth Wilson's performance particularly resonated: "I believed Ruth Wilson was Jane, the same spirit that soared in Brontë's words. When Ruth Wilson as Jane proclaimed her feelings to Mr. Rochester, I was in awe. This was the Jane I had always imagined."

### Long-term Legacy:
Both adaptations have maintained devoted followings:
- The 1983 and 2006 versions are frequently cited as top favorites: "the 1983 and 2006 versions remain among my top favorite adaptations of Jane Eyre" with both versions being "great and well done."
- Viewers often compare the two directly: "I'm a huge fan of the BBC's 2006 version" but "I too am a lover the Ruth Wilson/Toby Stephens 2006 adaptation, but I felt (good as it was) it could not come near this 1983 adaptation."

### Production Values:
The 2006 version is noted as "a very stylish and lavishly filmed production, with a series of almost cinematic scenes that hold great visual appeal. Even so, it never fails to engage the heart and mind as well as the eyes."

Both adaptations have had significant cultural impact, with passionate defenders of each version. The 1983 adaptation is praised for its faithfulness to the source material and Timothy Dalton's profound interpretation of Rochester's tortured character. The 2006 adaptation is celebrated for its production values, contemporary sensibility, and the chemistry between Ruth Wilson and Toby Stephens. Together, they represent two of the most influential and beloved adaptations of Charlotte Brontë's classic novel in television history.
